Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Carol \Car"ol\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Caroled}, or {Carolled}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Caroling}, or {Carolling}.] [1913 Webster] 1. To praise or celebrate in song. [1913 Webster]
The Shepherds at their festivals Carol her goodness. --Milton. [1913 Webster]
2. To sing, especially with joyful notes. [1913 Webster]
Hovering swans . . . carol sounds harmonious. --Prior. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Carol \Car"ol\, v. i. To sing; esp. to sing joyfully; to warble. [1913 Webster]
And carol of love's high praise. --Spenser. [1913 Webster]
The gray linnets carol from the hill. --Beattie. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Carol \Car"ol\, n. [OF. carole a kind of dance wherein many dance together, fr. caroler to dance; perh. from Celtic; cf. Armor. koroll, n., korolla, korolli, v., Ir. car music, turn, circular motion, also L. choraula a flute player, charus a dance, chorus, choir.] 1. A round dance. [Obs.] --Chaucer. [1913 Webster]
2. A song of joy, exultation, or mirth; a lay. [1913 Webster]
The costly feast, the carol, and the dance. --Dryden [1913 Webster]
It was the carol of a bird. --Byron. [1913 Webster]
3. A song of praise of devotion; as, a Christmas or Easter carol. [1913 Webster]
Heard a carol, mournful, holy. --Tennyson. [1913 Webster]
In the darkness sing your carol of high praise. --Keble. [1913 Webster]
4. Joyful music, as of a song. [1913 Webster]
I heard the bells on Christmans Day Their old, familiar carol play. --Longfellow. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Carol \Car"ol\, Carrol \Car"rol\, n. [OF. carole a sort of circular space, or carol.] (Arch.) A small closet or inclosure built against a window on the inner side, to sit in for study. The word was used as late as the 16th century. The term {carrel}, of the same has largely superseded its use. [1913 Webster +PJC]
A bay window may thus be called a carol. --Parker. [1913 Webster]

carol n 1: joyful religious song celebrating the birth of Christ [syn: {Christmas carol}] 2: a joyful song (usually celebrating the birth of Christ) v : sing carols; "They went caroling on Christmas Day" [also: {carolling}, {carolled}]
